column1: The manager of one of the great power-stations on the banks of the river above the Falls told me that the center of the riverbed at the Canadian Falls is deep and of a saucer shape. So
column2: it may be possible to fill this up to a uniform depth
column3: and divert a lot of water for the power-houses. And this
column5: would supply the need for more power
column7: without taking away from the beauty of Niagara. This is a handsome concession of the utilitarians to ordinary sightseers. Yet
column8: I doubt if we shall be satisfied. The real secret of the beauty and terror of the Falls is not their height or width
column9: but the feeling of colossal power and of unintelligible disaster caused by the plunge of that vast body of water. If that were taken away
column10: there would be little visible change
column11: but the heart would be gone.The American Falls do not inspire this feeling in the same way as the Canadian. It is because they are less in volume
column12: and because the water does not fall so much into one place. By comparison their beauty is almost delicate and fragile.
